content: If you're completely done with that account on that computer and don't need access to any emails, including the important ones that you searched for and found, just go to (in Windows) Tools | Account Settings and in the right pane you'll see a Delete button. This will remove the account from Thunderbird but won't affect the messages on the server.
creator: rednoise

content: Thanks, Lin. I'm on the Mac OS platform, but I'm imagining it works similarly to that. Will deleting the account delete the emails as well? Or do I need to go find those and delete them separately?
creator: 6rcvfytmqd

content: After you click the Delete button you'll be presented with a confirmation dialog box that includes a "Remove message data" option, which you will want to choose in this case. After you click the Remove button, everything associated with that account will be deleted from your computer (but not the server.)

creator: davidsk

content:
re : It has stopped allowing me to easily delete unwanted emails.

It may help to find out what is going on. I'm not sure what it is that you are suddenly finding difficult. Unwanted mail is generally labelled as Junk/Spam and if set up correctly they should be in the 'Spam/Junk' folder. A right click on Spam/Junk folder and select 'Empty Junk' should delete them. After emptying Junk - right click on folder and select 'Compact' to remove all traces.

If you have unwanted mail in eg: Inbox, you can mark as Junk and it should go to the accounts Junk/Spam folder. Or if unwanted mail is in 'Inbox' and you do not want to open it: Right click on email to see a menu. The Mark as Junk icon is at the top - it has a flame icon OR to delete click on the far right Trash icon and it should go into the account Trash folder.

There are several ways to delete an email.

What exactly is the problem ? What method do you normally use ?

re : Further, it is slow as molasses when trying to expand and read emails.

Are you using an Imap or Pop account ?

What Anti-Virus do you use ? I ask because many people allow their AV to scan any file that gets opened. That means Thunderbird can temporarilly be held up because AV has taken control over the file which manifests as a delay in proceedings. A pain in the proverbial. To be honest I advise people to access their Anti-Virus and set up an exemption to not scan the 'Thunderbird' profile folder: eg: C://User/<username>/Appdta/Roaming/Thunderbird After all, you do not want it to fix anything as it might cause data loss. AV products do not understand that one text file may contain hundreds of emails. If you still want it to scan those files, then at the very least do not allow AV to auto fix or quarrantine - tell it to ask what to do so you can stop any action.

Another thought - how frequently do you compact your folders ? Ideally the Inbox, Drafts and Spam/Junk should compacted on a regular basis especially after deleting or moving emails. I manually compact those three folders almost daily because I get quite a few emails. I also use Message Filters to help sort and organise emails into various folders, so a lot of emails get 'moved'. If you do not compact then the email remains in the original file, marked as deleted and hidden. That means the file may be a lot larger than you think. Not compacting can increase the risk of corruption, so it's a good thing to do as housekeeping maintenance.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
re : My understanding is that the 102 series version works better.

Not sure where you got that information. You need to be aware that some people do not like new designs even if they really are better so they become more vocal. But in reality the majority just get on with and find it's better than they initially thought especially when they realise there are alot more options. You tend to not hear much from those people. I'm using two version of Thunderbird at the moment. One is version 128.14.0esr and the other is beta 145.0b2 I do that because some people are still on the older version and I offer help, so need to know info. The beta means I'm able to test and check for any bugs etc. It also has all the visual data etc that is currently used the 144 version.

My experience is in all the versions and I would not say 102 series is a better option. It was a good version, but will not be using the most up to date security or bug fixes. It also will not have all the new functionalities and design display options. Some people are not aware of the new options. There has also been a huge change in the code as alot has been rewritten. If you go back then you can end up being very out date in a short amount of time.

I would be happy to help to see if something is not set up correctly which improves your experience. Many people have not yet got to grips with the new options and some never realised some older options were still available. eg: The new Unified Toolbar operates over various views such as Mail or Calendar etc and it can be customised in such a way that some new toolbars can be hidden to gain space/declutter. There is also two ways to view the Message List, eg: Table view or Card view. The list is quite lengthy, but if you want to see if you can improve the current situation, then let's see what we can achieve.

You might be think - ah well - it's alright for younger folk they adjust more easily. Sadly, I'm no spring chicken, so I do understand. But, it doesn't stop me from picking it up alot quicker than I may have initally thought.

However, if you really want to go backwards then you would need to do the following. I would always advise that you create a backup before you do this for obvious reasons :)

First make sure Thunderbird is not set up to auto update:

  • Settings > General
  • scroll down to 'Updates' section
  • select option 'check for updates. but let mew choose whether to install them'
  • Do not select/uncheck this option: 'Use a background service to install updates'

Unchecking that last option means even if you accidentally selected to update, the OS will pop up a UAC prompt to ask if you really want to allow the update, so you can say NO and stop it.

  • Exit Thunderbird - this is important.
  • Check computer for updater software

Make sure you do not have any other updater software on computer which may try to override. Some Anti-Virus products do offer auto checks for updates. I use Norton 360 and I know it offers checking for software updates. I had to stop it from checking for a Firefox and Thunderbird update. Let Firefox and Thunderbird control the updates when you say so.

Now access profile

  • In Windows search type: %Appdata% - see image below as guide
  • Select '%Appdata% file folder
  • Select 'Roaming'
  • Copy the 'Thunderbird' folder and paste in safe location such as an external hardrive or another partition eg: D: drive - this will be the backup.
  • Select 'Thunderbird' to see contents
  • Select 'Profiles'
  • Select the 'profile name' folder
  • Look for delete the 'compatibility.ini' file.
  • Uninstall Thunderbird.
  • Get a download from the appropriate version link - choose eg: win64 for a Windows OS. Then choose prefered language eg: en-GB = English British and then click on the 'Thunderbird version exe' file link to download.

Version 102.15.1

  • https://ftp.mozilla.org/pub/thunderbird/releases/102.15.1/

Version 128.14.0

  • https://ftp.mozilla.org/pub/thunderbird/releases/128.14.0esr/

2.Zkuste se přihlásit přímo přes webmail (např. na mail.seznam.cz, outlook.com, gmail.com apod.) a podívejte se, jestli tam e-mail s přílohou je. Pokud na webu e-mail vidíte, ale v Thunderbirdu ne, je problém v Thunderbirdu. Pokud ani na webu není, může ho blokovat poskytovatel nebo antispam.

creator: p.knotig

content:
Zkontroluj několik věcí:

Webmail / jiný klient: Otevři si schránku přes web (např. Seznam, Gmail, Centrum…). Jestli tam zpráva s přílohou je, ale v Thunderbirdu chybí, problém je v nastavení nebo v doplňku Thunderbirdu.

Filtry a antivir: Podívej se, jestli nemáš aktivní filtr, který maže nebo přesouvá zprávy s přílohou. Některé antiviry (např. Avast) také umí blokovat e-maily s přílohami.

Zobrazení v Thunderbirdu: V Nástroje → Nastavení účtů → Synchronizace a úložiště zkontroluj, jestli nemáš nastaveno “Nestahovat přílohy” nebo příliš malý limit pro stahování.

Zkus zrušit doplňky: V nouzovém režimu Thunderbirdu („Spustit v nouzovém režimu“) zjistíš, jestli přílohy nezačnou chodit po vypnutí rozšíření.

Protokol účtu: Pokud používáš POP3, může být problém s mazáním starých zpráv ze serveru. U IMAP by měly být přílohy vždy viditelné i přes webmail.

content:
Another data point:

If go to Settings - Copies & Folders, then turn off the "Place a Copy in - Sent folder" option, the messages send perfectly fine.

When turn that "Place a Copy in Sent Folder" back on, the behavior reappears.

I've also tried different SMTP settings with the same result. It appears the hiccup happens on the "Copy message to Sent folder" process when watching the Activity Monitor.

Kris

content: Actually, with IMAP, copies are on your PC. The main issue to remember is that they are deleted from PC if deleted from server. In moving to inbox, maybe if you mark the message unread, that may help. Long term, I suggest considering a switch to IMAP for your consistency and, when there is a message you want saved 'forever', to use the PC to COPY to Local Folders.

content:
Eric Meece (Eric Mystic) said
I checked it. I don't see where this supplied me a "go to inbox" option.

It doesn't give you a specific "Go to Inbox" option. It gives you a list of all folders, including the Inbox, any of which you can select. Such an option has never existed in Thunderbird since it was first released in the early 2000s. I think we can safely assume by now that we will never see it. Personally, I have never needed that option and it wouldn't be useful to me.
